bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Colonel Nicholas Smith, February 24, 1729

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Colonel Nicholas Smith of Richmond County, February 24, 1729, about militia commissions and to thank him for his sympathy on Carter's recent loss of his new house at Corotoman.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Colonel Nicholas Smith, February 24, 1729

opener.dateline:
[Corotoman, Lancaster County, Virginia]
Febry: 24th. 1728/9
Colo: Nicholas Smith

div1.p:
I receiv'd yours of the Twelfth not till Saturday
last maj: Thornton is Certainly mistaken to think that the
practice has been to send the Commissions Blank to the Command
ing Offrs residing in the County to be filld up by them at their
pleasure and to be distributed at a general muster at least I am
sure I never was Acquainted with such a practice the Govrs: I
have been Acquainted with have never entrusted me with the blank
commissions before this and but have Always had them filld up them
selves upon the return of my Lists however being well assured o[f]
yr. Sincerity I now send them to you not doubting you will pitch i[n]
the best and fittest men for Capts: that your County will afford it [is]
highly necessary there be a Capt Appointed somewhere about the ma[. . .]
for the Upper Company Russel now lives in Staffd: and who to
recommend as a fit person in those parts for his place I am to[o]
much a Stranger to do offer at

Capt Strother is as fit a person in my Opinion a[s]
any that lives near him and I should not be for leaving him
out but if he absolutely refuses to Serve I dont know how tht
is to be helpd I am
div1.closer:
Sir
Yr most humble Servt.
were I master of a vein to
match your wit a[s] well as your Lady is &ca: you might expect some th[i]
ng of that nature from me but you know my Talent is too flat f[or]
such Excursions I thank you kindly for the tenderness you express of
my late Suffering & am

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1728 August-1731 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.
The name of Carter's home, "Corotoman," the county, and colony have been added for clarity to this unheaded draft.
[1] Major William Thornton (d. 1742/43) of King George County. (King George County Virginia Will Book A-1 1721-1752 And Miscellaneous Notes. [Fredericksburg, VA: Privately Printed, 1978], p. 277.)
[2] Carter had built a fine house at Corotoman in the mid 1720s, but it burned at the end of January 1729. See the Maryland Gazette for 1728/29 February 4-11 for information about Carter's loss.
